_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Calumet Lubricants Company-Shreveport Refinery has a long-standing commitment to employee and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention such as safety training and incident investigation.  Safety is considered in the design, construction, operation and maintenance of our processes.  Caumet's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  In the occurrence of a release, our trained emergency response personnel shall respond to control and contain the release.   The facility has experienced one accidental release in the past five years.  This release occurred under the ownership of Pennzoil-Quaker State.  The unit is no longer used under the business plan of Calumet Lubricants.

OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY

The Plant Manager has the overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program.  To ensure that our risk management program is appropriately developed and implemented, our Plant Manager has assigned the role of Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program to a staff member with the necessary background, training, and experience.  An Environmental, Health and Safety Engineer (PSM/RMP Coordinator), acting with the authority delegated directly from the Plant Manager, has the responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP elements and the elements of Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) PSM program (where applicable), as required under Section 68.15 of the RMP rule.  

The following sections identify the specific responsibilities for each aspect of our risk management and process safety management programs.

2 HAZARD ASSESSMENTS

The Environmental, Health, and Safety Engineers have the responsibility for: (1) ensuring that o

ffsite consequence analysis for each regulated process are consistently performed and documented in accordance with Sections 68.20 through 68.39 and (2) selecting the scenarios that will be reported in the facility RMPlan as required under Section 68.165. 

3 PREVENTION PROGRAMS

The Environmental, Health, and Safety Engineers have the responsibility for ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant prevention program that meets EPA RMP (Sections 68.65 through 68.87 of the RMP rule) and OSHA PSM requirements.  

3.1 Process Safety Information

The responsibility for process safety information (PSI) (Section 68.65 of the RMP rule) is divided into three areas. The PSM/RMP Coordinator has responsibility for process chemical information, the Process Engineer has responsibility for process technology information and the Plant Engineer has responsibility for equipment information.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator also has the responsibility of ensuring that all of this information is readily accessible for use.

3.2 Process Hazard Analysis

In accordance with Section 68.67 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that process hazard analyses (PHAs) are scheduled, conducted, and documented by trained personnel for all regulated processes.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator identifies candidate PHA team leaders from within the facility and ensures that they receive appropriate training before leading PHAs.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator may utilize outside contractors to lead PHAs when appropriate.  

3.3 Operating Procedures

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the facility's Supervisors have the responsibility for ensuring that complete and accurate operating procedures are in place for regulated processes.  The Supervisors work closely with the PSM/RMP Coordinator to develop and maintain the facility's safe work practices.  The procedures are stored in the plant's electronic document control system.

3.4 Training

In acc

ordance with Section 68.71 of the RMP rule, the Operational Supervisors have the responsibility for:  (1) ensuring that operations employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and the associated processes and (2) documenting the training. The PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that all facility employees receive and understand training in safe work practices applicable to their jobs.  The Maintenance Manager has the responsibility for: (1) ensuring that maintenance employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and the mechanical integrity program and documenting the training.

3.5 Mechanical Integrity

In accordance with Section 68.73 of the RMP rule, the Plant Engineer has the responsibility for developing the mechanical integrity program with specific emphasis on written procedures, equipment and instrumentation inspection/test programs and documentation, and equipment deficiency resolution.  The Maintenance Manager also has the responsibility for implementing the mechanical integrity program and maintenance training.  The Purchasing Clerk working with the Purchasing Manager insures that appropriate quality assurance procedures are followed for all types of equipment acquisitions, installations and repairs.

3.6 Management of Change

In accordance with Section 68.75 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for the overall management of change (MOC) program; however, the Plant Manager, the Operational Supervisors, and the Plant Engineer have responsibility for ensuring that the overall MOC program is effectively implemented in their areas.

3.7 Pre-Startup Review

In accordance with Section 68.77 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for the overall pre-startup review program, which is closely related to the MOC program. However, the Operational Supervisors have the primary responsibility for ensuring that this program is effectively im

plemented before affected operations begin.


3.8 Compliance Audits

In accordance with Section 68.79 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that compliance audits occur at least every three years and are documented to verify that the prevention program is working and meets EPA/OSHA requirements.  

3.9 Incident Investigation

In accordance with Section 68.81 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for designing and managing the incident investigation program, including tracking resolution of investigation findings and recommendations.  The PSM/RMP Coordinator also has the responsibility of ensuring that only trained personnel lead our investigations.  Each area supervisor has responsibility for ensuring that all incidents in their areas are reported and investigated and the investigation findings are resolved, documented, and communicated to the affected personnel.

3.10 Employee Participation

In accordance with Section 68.83 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility of involving employees in the planning and implementation of the facility's prevention program elements.

3.11 Hot Work Permits

In accordance with Section 68.85 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator, working closely with the Operational Supervisors and the Maintenance Manager, has the responsibility of developing and maintaining the facility's hot work permit program.

3.12 Contractors

In accordance with Section 68.87 of the RMP rule, the Plant Engineer has the overall responsibility for the contractor program; however, the Maintenance Manager and the Purchasing Clerk are responsible for ensuring that the requirements of the program are implemented.

4 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

In accordance with Sections 68.90 and 68.95 of the RMP rule, the PSM/RMP Coordinator is responsible for:  (1) designing, implementing, and maintaining the facility's emergency response plan, (2) ensuring that all associated training is co

nducted and documented as necessary, (3) coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community emergency response plan, and (4) responding to local emergency planners/responders when questions arise.

5 RMPLAN PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION

The PSM/RMP Coordinator is responsible for preparing and submitting the RMPlan for the facility (after review and approval by the Plant Manager) as required under Sections 68.150 through 68.185 of the RMP rule.

6 RMPLAN COMMUNICATION

The Plant Manager or his designee has the responsibility of providing RMPlan information (other than the required EPA submission) to employees and the public as required under Section 68.210 of the RMP rule.
